1084588415461384193.text: Where does it end? Even if the thief ‶wins″ they end up with less money than when they started. 9/10

1084588414370889729.text: -and likewise, for the exchange, the options are: -X - k*Y vs -(k+1)*Y …the latter is a much smaller loss, so in a reductionist-greedy strategy it is the better choice. 8/10

1084588413259411456.text: Doesn't matter, still more than the very negative -k*Y, so by a naive-greedy analysis of ‶the next move″, the thief should always continue the attack. 7/10

1084588412252770304.text: Eventually, the thief is faced with the option, after k attacks of: -k*Y vs X - (k+1)*Y … what happens when X - (k+1)*Y is about 0? 6/10

1084588411246104576.text: Back to the exchange, the options are: -X - Y vs -2*Y … 5/10

1084588409425846272.text: Now the thief has two options: stop the attack after spending Y without the loot, or spend about Y again to regain the loot: -Y vs X - 2*Y … 4/10

1084588408322674688.text: The exchange has two options: lose X, vs spend about Y to undo the theft. Those choices have delta -X vs -Y. Say they take the second option… 3/10

1084588407194497025.text: Suppose a thief has just spent Y to rollback a chain and thereby revert a deposit worth X with an exchange… That's a delta of X - Y. (Y is much less than X.) 2/10

1050789390614581248.text: Censorship resistance can become locally detectable through ‶local subnetwork effects″. Ex: if it's easier to get CC by mining in Venezuela than to get cash dollars, there's potential for a geographically local network effect due to censorship resistance. 5/6

1050789389779881985.text: Users *can't see* privacy and sound money properties locally. So a currency can't compete on those properties alone. Those properties only help globally on large time scales. 4/6

1050789388823670785.text: End users can see transaction fees, times, UI complexity as direct properties. They can ‶see″ network effect locally, even though it's an emergent property. 3/6

1050789387972141056.text: End users rarely care, nor can even *detect*, global emergent properties. They can only notice local properties, whether direct or emergent. 2/6

1050789386877468672.text: The ‶Bitcoin is sound money so it will inevitably dominate″ narrative is dangerous and lazy. It reminds me of my faith in my youth that privacy would prevail in tech. 1/6

1016072701411119104.text: …Ethics: I *personally* don't support any compelled speech or compelled non-speech, so on those grounds I would say anyone can call anything they want Zcash (or Zcrash or Bitcoin or whatevs). I also believe that trademark laws exist, and that the company can & should use that.

1016072700534460416.text: …Ethics: I *personally* don't consider anyone advocating that other people should run different variants of the Zcash codebase to be akin to theft or appropriation. Also, they have no authority to compel what software I run.

1016072699678879745.text: Onto ethics: I *personally* believe and support everyone's right to say anything they want, to assemble into any groups they want, to modify and run any software they want on their own devices. (Note: I don't think the company can/should refrain from moderating the forum.)

1016072698751942656.text: Now for *non-Capabilities*: ZcashCo does NOT operate: any mainnet miners, a lot of Tor infrastructure, distribution of *any* end user GUI/mobile wallets, any mainnet block explorers, http://zcashcommunity.com , /r/zec, the telegram channel.

1016072697099403264.text: …Capabilities: ZcashCo operates the dns seeder nodes. Would love to see others operate those. And finally, of course the "Zcash" github org and repo.

1016072696260521990.text: …Capabilities: ZcashCo operates http://forum.z.cash , which is unnecessary centralization. I personally would love to see the locus of communication migrate somewhere outside the control of the company.

1016072695367151616.text: Next, everyone should be aware of centralized capabilities. ZcashCo owns and controls a Zcash trademark, so if the community altered consensus rules in some manner, ZcashCo may exercise legal capabilities around the trademark (ie: compel another project to change it's name/logo).

1016072694503124992.text: I personally am least interested in the legal obligations of ZcashCo for this discussion, because for *that* it doesn't matter what outsiders think, and also I am much more interested in the bigger picture of Zcash.

1016072693660020736.text: Obligations: ZcashCo has a legal contract about distributing “the Founders' Reward”. I am unclear, legally, if a chainsplit occurs where both sides have FR pointing to the same addresses, or if only a single chain exists that alters the FR schedule (or any other monetary policy).

1016072692758220800.text: I'd like to share my thoughts several facets of the proposal: obligations, capabilities, ethics, and preferences. (These are not necessarily shared across ZcashCo or the Foundation.)
